00015 
00016 // symbol macros which may be swapped to use common symbol pointers for performance
00017 #define USESYM(x)   gensym(#x)
00018 //#define USESYM(x) _sym_##x
00019 
00020 // macros for attributes
00021 // class attributes are almost universally attr_offset, except for class static attributes
00022 
00023 
00024 /**
00025     Create a char attribute and add it to a Max class.
00026 
00027     @ingroup    attr
00028     @param  c               The class pointer.
00029     @param  attrname        The name of this attribute as a C-string.
00030     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
00031     @param  structname      The C identifier for the struct (containing a valid #t_object header) representing an instance of this class.
00032     @param  structmember    The C identifier of the member in the struct that holds the value of this attribute.
00033 */
00034 #define CLASS_ATTR_CHAR(c,attrname,flags,structname,structmember) \
00035     class_addattr((c),attr_offset_new(attrname,USESYM(char),(flags),(method)0L,(method)0L,calcoffset(structname,structmember)))
00036 
00037 
00038 /**
00039     Create a long integer attribute and add it to a Max class.
00040 
00041     @ingroup    attr
00042     @param  c               The class pointer.
00043     @param  attrname        The name of this attribute as a C-string.
00044     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
00045     @param  structname      The C identifier for the struct (containing a valid #t_object header) representing an instance of this class.
00046     @param  structmember    The C identifier of the member in the struct that holds the value of this attribute.
00047 */
00048 #define CLASS_ATTR_LONG(c,attrname,flags,structname,structmember) \
00049     class_addattr((c),attr_offset_new(attrname,USESYM(long),(flags),(method)0L,(method)0L,calcoffset(structname,structmember)))

00124 /**
00125     Create an array-of-chars attribute of fixed length, and add it to a Max class.
00126 
00127     @ingroup    attr
00128     @param  c               The class pointer.
00129     @param  attrname        The name of this attribute as a C-string.
00130     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
00131     @param  structname      The C identifier for the struct (containing a valid #t_object header) representing an instance of this class.
00132     @param  structmember    The C identifier of the member in the struct that holds the value of this attribute.
00133     @param  size            The number of chars in the array.
00134 */
00135 #define CLASS_ATTR_CHAR_ARRAY(c,attrname,flags,structname,structmember,size) \
00136     class_addattr((c),attr_offset_array_new(attrname,USESYM(char),(size),(flags),(method)0L,(method)0L,0/*fix*/,calcoffset(structname,structmember)))

00231 /**
00232     Create an array-of-chars attribute of variable length, and add it to a Max class.
00233 
00234     @ingroup    attr
00235     @param  c               The class pointer.
00236     @param  attrname        The name of this attribute as a C-string.
00237     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
00238     @param  structname      The C identifier for the struct (containing a valid #t_object header) representing an instance of this class.
00239     @param  structmember    The C identifier of the member in the struct that holds the value of this attribute.
00240     @param  sizemember      The actual number of items in the char array at any given moment.
00241     @param  maxsize         The maximum number of items in the char array, i.e. the number of members allocated for the array in the struct.
00242 */
00243 #define CLASS_ATTR_CHAR_VARSIZE(c,attrname,flags,structname,structmember,sizemember,maxsize) \
00244     class_addattr((c),attr_offset_array_new(attrname,USESYM(char),(maxsize),(flags),(method)0L,(method)0L,calcoffset(structname,sizemember),calcoffset(structname,structmember)))
00245 
00246 
00247 /**
00248     Create an array-of-long-integers attribute of variable length, and add it to a Max class.
00249 
00250     @ingroup    attr
00251     @param  c               The class pointer.
00252     @param  attrname        The name of this attribute as a C-string.
00253     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
00254     @param  structname      The C identifier for the struct (containing a valid #t_object header) representing an instance of this class.
00255     @param  structmember    The C identifier of the member in the struct that holds the value of this attribute.
00256     @param  sizemember      The actual number of items in the long array at any given moment.
00257     @param  maxsize         The maximum number of items in the long array, i.e. the number of members allocated for the array in the struct.
00258 */
00259 #define CLASS_ATTR_LONG_VARSIZE(c,attrname,flags,structname,structmember,sizemember,maxsize) \
00260     class_addattr((c),attr_offset_array_new(attrname,USESYM(long),(maxsize),(flags),(method)0L,(method)0L,calcoffset(structname,sizemember),calcoffset(structname,structmember)))

00345 // "struct" attributes are just like class attributes, but the struct member name is the same as the attribute name
00346 // we use CMacro "stringification" in this case
00347 
00348 // scalar variants
00349 
00350 /**
00351     Create a char attribute and add it to a Max class.
00352     The name of the attribute is automatically determined by the name of the struct member.
00353 
00354     @ingroup    attr
00355     @param  c               The class pointer.
00356     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
00357     @param  structname      The C identifier for the struct (containing a valid #t_object header) representing an instance of this class.
00358     @param  structmember    The C identifier of the member in the struct that holds the value of this attribute.
00359 */
00360 #define STRUCT_ATTR_CHAR(c,flags,structname,structmember)       CLASS_ATTR_CHAR(c,#structmember,flags,structname,structmember)
00361 
00362 
00363 /**
00364     Create a long integer attribute and add it to a Max class.
00365     The name of the attribute is automatically determined by the name of the struct member.
00366 
00367     @ingroup    attr

00370     @param  structname      The C identifier for the struct (containing a valid #t_object header) representing an instance of this class.
00371     @param  structmember    The C identifier of the member in the struct that holds the value of this attribute.
00372 */
00373 #define STRUCT_ATTR_LONG(c,flags,structname,structmember)       CLASS_ATTR_LONG(c,#structmember,flags,structname,structmember)

00434     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
00435     @param  structname      The C identifier for the struct (containing a valid #t_object header) representing an instance of this class.
00436     @param  structmember    The C identifier of the member in the struct that holds the value of this attribute.
00437 */
00438 #define STRUCT_ATTR_OBJ(c,flags,structname,structmember)        CLASS_ATTR_OBJ(c,#structmember,flags,structname,structmember)

00556     @param  maxsize         The maximum number of items in the char array, i.e. the number of members allocated for the array in the struct.
00557 */

00901 #define OBJ_ATTR_SYM(x,attrname,flags,val)      OBJ_ATTR_FORMAT(x,attrname,USESYM(symbol),flags,"s",val)

01023 
01024 /**
01025     Specify custom accessor methods for an attribute.  
01026     If you specify a non-NULL value for the setter or getter, 
01027     then the function you specify will be called to set or get the attribute's value
01028     rather than using the built-in accessor.
01029 
01030     @ingroup    attr
01031     @param  c               The class pointer.
01032     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01033     @param  getter          An appropriate getter method as discussed in @ref attribute_accessors, 
01034                             or NULL to use the default getter.
01035     @param  setter          An appropriate setter method as discussed in @ref attribute_accessors, 
01036                             or NULL to use the default setter.
01037 */
01038 #define CLASS_ATTR_ACCESSORS(c,attrname,getter,setter) \
01039     { t_object *theattr=(t_object *)class_attr_get(c,gensym(attrname)); \
01040         object_method(theattr,gensym("setmethod"),USESYM(get),getter); \
01041         object_method(theattr,gensym("setmethod"),USESYM(set),setter); }
01042 
01043 
01044 /**
01045     Add flags to an attribute.  
01046 
01047     @ingroup    attr
01048     @param  c               The class pointer.
01049     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01050     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to add to this attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01051 */
01052 #define CLASS_ATTR_ADD_FLAGS(c,attrname,flags) \
01053     { t_object *theattr=(t_object *)class_attr_get(c,gensym(attrname)); \
01054         long oldflags = object_method(theattr,gensym("getflags")); \
01055         object_method(theattr,gensym("setflags"),oldflags|(flags)); }
01056 
01057 
01058 /**
01059     Remove flags from an attribute.  
01060 
01061     @ingroup    attr
01062     @param  c               The class pointer.
01063     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01064     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to remove from this attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01065 */
01066 #define CLASS_ATTR_REMOVE_FLAGS(c,attrname,flags) \
01067     { t_object *theattr=(t_object *)class_attr_get(c,gensym(attrname)); \
01068         long oldflags = object_method(theattr,gensym("getflags")); \
01069         object_method(theattr,gensym("setflags"),oldflags&(~(flags))); }
01070 
01071 
01072 /**
01073     Add a filter to the attribute to limit the lower bound of a value.
01074     The limiting will be performed by the default attribute accessor.
01075 
01076     @ingroup    attr
01077     @param  c               The class pointer.
01078     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01079     @param  minval          The minimum acceptable value to which the attribute will be limited.
01080     @see    CLASS_ATTR_FILTER_MAX
01081     @see    CLASS_ATTR_FILTER_CLIP
01082     @see    CLASS_ATTR_MIN
01083 */
01084 #define CLASS_ATTR_FILTER_MIN(c,attrname,minval) \
01085     { t_object *theattr=(t_object *)class_attr_get(c,gensym(attrname)); \
01086         attr_addfilter_clip(theattr,minval,0,1,0); }
01087 
01088 
01089 /**
01090     Add a filter to the attribute to limit the upper bound of a value.
01091     The limiting will be performed by the default attribute accessor.
01092 
01093     @ingroup    attr
01094     @param  c               The class pointer.
01095     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01096     @param  maxval          The maximum acceptable value to which the attribute will be limited.
01097     @see    CLASS_ATTR_FILTER_MIN
01098     @see    CLASS_ATTR_FILTER_CLIP
01099     @see    CLASS_ATTR_MAX
01100 */
01101 #define CLASS_ATTR_FILTER_MAX(c,attrname,maxval) \
01102     { t_object *theattr=(t_object *)class_attr_get(c,gensym(attrname)); \
01103         attr_addfilter_clip(theattr,0,maxval,0,1); }
01104 
01105 
01106 /**
01107     Add a filter to the attribute to limit both the lower and upper bounds of a value.
01108     The limiting will be performed by the default attribute accessor.
01109 
01110     @ingroup    attr
01111     @param  c               The class pointer.
01112     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01113     @param  minval          The maximum acceptable value to which the attribute will be limited.
01114     @param  maxval          The maximum acceptable value to which the attribute will be limited.
01115     @see 
01116 */
01117 #define CLASS_ATTR_FILTER_CLIP(c,attrname,minval,maxval) \
01118     { t_object *theattr=(t_object *)class_attr_get(c,gensym(attrname)); \
01119         attr_addfilter_clip(theattr,minval,maxval,1,1); }
01120 
01121 
01122 /**
01123     Create a new attribute that is an alias of an existing attribute.
01124 
01125     @ingroup    attr
01126     @param  c               The class pointer.
01127     @param  attrname        The name of the actual attribute as a C-string.
01128     @param  aliasname       The name of the new alias attribute.
01129 */
01130 #define CLASS_ATTR_ALIAS(c,attrname,aliasname) \
01131     {   t_object *thealias; \
01132         t_object *theattr=(t_object *)class_attr_get(c,gensym(attrname)); \
01133         thealias = object_clone(theattr); \
01134         object_method(thealias,USESYM(setname),gensym(aliasname)); \
01135         class_addattr(c,thealias); \
01136         CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(c,aliasname,"alias",USESYM(symbol),0,attrname); }
01137

01144 #define CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_FORMAT  class_attr_addattr_format

01147 /**
01148     Add a new attribute to the specified attribute to specify a default value.
01149     The default value will be automatically set when the object is created only if your object uses a dictionary constructor
01150     with the #CLASS_FLAG_NEWDICTIONARY flag.
01151 
01152     @ingroup    attr
01153     @param  c               The class pointer.
01154     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01155     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01156     @param  parsestr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01157 */
01158 #define CLASS_ATTR_DEFAULT(c,attrname,flags,parsestr) \
01159     { t_object *theattr=(t_object *)class_attr_get(c,gensym(attrname)); CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(c,attrname,"default",(t_symbol *)object_method(theattr,USESYM(gettype)),flags,parsestr); }
01160

01189 /**
01190     Add a new attribute to the specified attribute to specify a default value, based on Max's Object Defaults.
01191     If a value is present in Max's Object Defaults, then that value will be used as the default value.
01192     Otherwise, use the default value specified here.
01193     The default value will be automatically set when the object is created only if your object uses a dictionary constructor
01194     with the #CLASS_FLAG_NEWDICTIONARY flag.
01195 
01196     @ingroup    attr
01197     @param  c               The class pointer.
01198     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01199     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01200     @param  parsestr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01201 */
01202 #define CLASS_ATTR_DEFAULTNAME(c,attrname,flags,parsestr) \
01203     { t_object *theattr=(t_object *)class_attr_get(c,gensym(attrname)); CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(c,attrname,"defaultname",(t_symbol *)object_method(theattr,USESYM(gettype)),flags,parsestr); }

01336 /**
01337     Add a new attribute to the specified attribute to specify an editor style for the Max inspector.
01338     Available styles include
01339     <ul>
01340         <li>"text"      : a text editor</li>
01341         <li>"onoff"     : a toggle switch</li>
01342         <li>"rgba"      : a color chooser</li>
01343         <li>"enum"      : a menu of available choices, whose symbol will be passed upon selection</li>
01344         <li>"enumindex" : a menu of available choices, whose index will be passed upon selection</li>
01345         <li>"rect"      : a style for displaying and editing #t_rect values</li>
01346         <li>"font"      : a font chooser</li>
01347     </ul>
01348 
01349     @ingroup    attr
01350     @param  c               The class pointer.
01351     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01352     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01353     @param  parsestr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01354 */
01355 #define CLASS_ATTR_STYLE(c,attrname,flags,parsestr) \
01356     CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(c,attrname,"style",USESYM(symbol),flags,parsestr)
01357 
01358 
01359 /**
01360     Add a new attribute to the specified attribute to specify an a human-friendly label for the Max inspector.
01361

01365     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01366     @param  labelstr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01367 */
01368 #define CLASS_ATTR_LABEL(c,attrname,flags,labelstr) \
01369     CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_FORMAT(c,attrname,"label",USESYM(symbol),flags,"s",gensym(labelstr))

01372 /**
01373     Add a new attribute to the specified attribute to specify a list of choices to display in a menu
01374     for the Max inspector.
01375 
01376     @ingroup    attr
01377     @param  c               The class pointer.
01378     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01379     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01380     @param  parsestr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01381     
01382     @remark This macro automatically calls
01383     @code
01384     CLASS_ATTR_STYLE(c,attrname,flags,"enum").
01385     @endcode
01386     
01387     @see    CLASS_ATTR_ENUMINDEX
01388 */
01389 #define CLASS_ATTR_ENUM(c,attrname,flags,parsestr) \
01390     { CLASS_ATTR_STYLE(c,attrname,flags,"enum"); CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(c,attrname,"enumvals",USESYM(atom),flags,parsestr); }

01392 
01393 /**
01394     Add a new attribute to the specified attribute to specify a list of choices to display in a menu
01395     for the Max inspector.
01396 
01397     @ingroup    attr
01398     @param  c               The class pointer.
01399     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01400     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01401     @param  parsestr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01402     
01403     @remark This macro automatically calls
01404     @code
01405     CLASS_ATTR_STYLE(c,attrname,flags,"enumindex").
01406     @endcode
01407     
01408     @see    CLASS_ATTR_ENUM
01409 */
01410 #define CLASS_ATTR_ENUMINDEX(c,attrname,flags,parsestr) \
01411     { CLASS_ATTR_STYLE(c,attrname,flags,"enumindex"); CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(c,attrname,"enumvals",USESYM(atom),flags,parsestr); }
01412 
01413 
01414 /**
01415     Add a new attribute to the specified attribute to specify a category to which the attribute is assigned
01416     in the Max inspector.  
01417     Categories are represented in the inspector as tabs.  
01418     If the specified category does not exist then it will be created.
01419 
01420     @ingroup    attr
01421     @param  c               The class pointer.
01422     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01423     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01424     @param  parsestr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01425 */
01426 #define CLASS_ATTR_CATEGORY(c,attrname,flags,parsestr) \
01427     CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(c,attrname,"category",USESYM(symbol),flags,parsestr)
01428 
01429 
01430 /**
01431     A convenience wrapper for #CLASS_ATTR_STYLE, and #CLASS_ATTR_LABEL.
01432 
01433     @ingroup    attr
01434     @param  c               The class pointer.
01435     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01436     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01437     @param  stylestr        A C-string that names the style for the attribute. 
01438                             See #CLASS_ATTR_STYLE for the available styles.
01439     @param  labelstr        A C-string that names the category to which the attribute is assigned in the inspector.
01440 
01441     @see    CLASS_ATTR_STYLE
01442     @see    CLASS_ATTR_LABEL
01443 */
01444 #define CLASS_ATTR_STYLE_LABEL(c,attrname,flags,stylestr,labelstr) \
01445     { CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(c,attrname,"style",USESYM(symbol),flags,stylestr); CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_FORMAT(c,attrname,"label",USESYM(symbol),flags,"s",gensym(labelstr)); }  
01446 
01447 
01448 /**
01449     Add a new attribute to the specified attribute to flag an attribute as invisible to the Max inspector.  
01450 
01451     @ingroup    attr
01452     @param  c               The class pointer.
01453     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01454     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01455 */
01456 #define CLASS_ATTR_INVISIBLE(c,attrname,flags) \
01457     CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(c,attrname,"invisible",USESYM(long),flags,"1")
01458 
01459 
01460 /**
01461     Add a new attribute to the specified attribute to specify a default order in which to list attributes.  
01462 
01463     @ingroup    attr
01464     @param  c               The class pointer.
01465     @param  attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01466     @param  flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01467     @param  parsestr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01468     
01469     @remark A value of zero indicates that there is no ordering.  Ordering values begin at 1.  For example:
01470     @code
01471     CLASS_ATTR_ORDER(c, "firstattr",    0, "1");
01472     CLASS_ATTR_ORDER(c, "secondattr",   0, "2");
01473     CLASS_ATTR_ORDER(c, "thirdattr",    0, "3");
01474     @endcode
01475 */
01476 #define CLASS_ATTR_ORDER(c,attrname,flags,parsestr) \
01477     CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(c,attrname,"order",USESYM(long),flags,parsestr)
01478 
01479 
01480     
01481 // useful attr attr macro for objects that embed binary data as base64
01482 
01483 #define CLASS_ATTR_ATOMARRAY(c,attrname,flags) \
01484     CLASS_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(c,attrname,"atomarray",USESYM(long),flags,"1")
01485 
01486         // attach attrs to class methods
01487 #define CLASS_METHOD_ATTR_PARSE(c,methodname,attrname,type,flags,parsestring) \
01488     {   t_hashtab *methods=NULL; \
01489         t_object *m=NULL; \
01490         methods = (t_hashtab *)class_extra_lookup(c,gensym("methods")); \
01491         if (methods) { \
01492             hashtab_lookup(methods,gensym((methodname)),&m); \
01493             if (m) \
01494                 object_addattr_parse(m,attrname,type,flags,parsestring); \
01495         } \
01496     } 
01497 
01498 
01499 #define OBJ_ATTR_ATTR_ATOMS     object_attr_addattr_atoms
01500 #define OBJ_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE     object_attr_addattr_parse
01501 #define OBJ_ATTR_ATTR_FORMAT    object_attr_addattr_format
01502 
01503 
01504 /**
01505     An instance-attribute version of #CLASS_ATTR_DEFAULT.
01506 
01507     @ingroup    attr
01508     @param      x               The #t_object instance pointer.
01509     @param      attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01510     @param      flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01511     @param      parsestr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01512     @see        CLASS_ATTR_DEFAULT
01513 */
01514 #define OBJ_ATTR_DEFAULT(x,attrname,flags,parsestr) \
01515     { t_object *theattr=(t_object *)object_attr_get(x,gensym(attrname)); OBJ_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(x,attrname,"default",(t_symbol *)object_method(theattr,USESYM(gettype)),flags,parsestr); }

01519     An instance-attribute version of #CLASS_ATTR_SAVE.
01520 
01521     @ingroup    attr
01522     @param      x               The #t_object instance pointer.
01523     @param      attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01524     @param      flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01525     @see        CLASS_ATTR_SAVE
01526 */
01527 #define OBJ_ATTR_SAVE(x,attrname,flags) \
01528     OBJ_ATTR_ATTR_PARSE(x,attrname,"save",USESYM(long),flags,"1")

01532     An instance-attribute version of #CLASS_ATTR_DEFAULT_SAVE.

01535     @param      x               The #t_object instance pointer.
01536     @param      attrname        The name of the attribute as a C-string.
01537     @param      flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01538     @param      parsestr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01539     @see        CLASS_ATTR_DEFAULT_SAVE
01540 */
01541 #define OBJ_ATTR_DEFAULT_SAVE(x,attrname,flags,parsestr) \
01542     { OBJ_ATTR_DEFAULT(x,attrname,flags,parsestr); OBJ_ATTR_SAVE(x,attrname,flags); }
01543 
01544 
01545 // sticky macros for attribute attributes, and method attributes. Useful for defining attribute groups
01546 
01547 /**
01548     Create an attribute, and add it to all following attribute declarations.
01549     The block is closed by a call to #CLASS_STICKY_ATTR_CLEAR.
01550 
01551     @ingroup    attr
01552     @param      c               The class pointer.
01553     @param      name            The name of the new attribute to create as a C-string.
01554     @param      flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01555     @param      parsestr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01556     
01557     @remark     The most common use of CLASS_STICKY_ATTR is for creating multiple attributes with the same category,
01558                 as in this example:
01559     @code
01560     CLASS_STICKY_ATTR(c, "category", 0, "Foo");
01561     
01562     CLASS_ATTR_DOUBLE(c, "bar", 0, t_myobject, x_bar);
01563     CLASS_ATTR_LABEL(c, "bar", 0, "A Bar");
01564 
01565     CLASS_ATTR_CHAR(c, "switch", 0, t_myobject, x_switch);
01566     CLASS_ATTR_STYLE_LABEL(c, "switch", 0, "onoff", "Bar Switch");
01567 
01568     CLASS_ATTR_DOUBLE(c, "flow", 0, t_myobject, x_flow);
01569     CLASS_ATTR_LABEL(c, "flow", 0, "Flow Amount");
01570     
01571     CLASS_STICKY_ATTR_CLEAR(c, "category");
01572     @endcode
01573     
01574     @see        CLASS_STICKY_ATTR_CLEAR
01575 */
01576 #define CLASS_STICKY_ATTR(c,name,flags,parsestr) \
01577     { t_object *attr = attribute_new_parse(name,NULL,flags,parsestr); class_sticky(c,gensym("sticky_attr"),gensym(name),attr); }
01578 
01579 
01580 /**
01581     Close a #CLASS_STICKY_ATTR block.
01582 
01583     @ingroup    attr
01584     @param      c               The class pointer.
01585     @param      name            The name of the sticky attribute as a C-string.
01586     @see        CLASS_STICKY_ATTR
01587 */
01588 #define CLASS_STICKY_ATTR_CLEAR(c,name) class_sticky_clear(c,gensym("sticky_attr"),name?gensym(name):NULL)
01589 
01590 
01591 /**
01592     Create an attribute, and add it to all following method declarations.
01593     The block is closed by a call to #CLASS_STICKY_METHOD_CLEAR.
01594 
01595     @ingroup    attr
01596     @param      c               The class pointer.
01597     @param      name            The name of the new attribute to create as a C-string.
01598     @param      flags           Any flags you wish to declare for this new attribute, as defined in #e_max_attrflags.
01599     @param      parsestr        A C-string, which will be parsed into an array of atoms to set the initial value.
01600     
01601     @remark     The most common use of CLASS_STICKY_ATTR is for creating multiple attributes with the same category,
01602                 as in this example:
01603     @code
01604     CLASS_STICKY_ATTR(c, "undocumented", 0, "1");
01605     
01606     // add some methods here with class_add_method()
01607     // the undocumented attribute for methods means that the ref-page 
01608     // generator will ignore these methods.
01609     
01610     CLASS_STICKY_ATTR_CLEAR(c, "undocumented");
01611     @endcode
01612     
01613     @see        CLASS_STICKY_METHOD_CLEAR
01614 */
01615 #define CLASS_STICKY_METHOD(c,name,flags,parsestr) \
01616     { t_object *attr = attribute_new_parse(name,NULL,flags,parsestr); class_sticky(c,gensym("sticky_method"),gensym(name),attr); }
01617 
01618 
01619 /**
01620     Close a #CLASS_STICKY_METHOD block.
01621 
01622     @ingroup    attr
01623     @param      c               The class pointer.
01624     @param      name            The name of the sticky attribute as a C-string.
01625     @see        CLASS_STICKY_METHOD
01626 */
01627 #define CLASS_STICKY_METHOD_CLEAR(c,name) class_sticky_clear(c,gensym("sticky_method"),name?gensym(name):clear)
01628

01630 
01631 
01632 // support for long lists
01633 
01634 #define OBEX_UTIL_MAX_ATOM_GETBYTES     4095 
01635 #define OBEX_UTIL_MAX_ATOM_STATIC       2048
01636 
01637 
01638 //static memory case
01639 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_SETUP_VAR_STATIC t_atom atemp[OBEX_UTIL_MAX_ATOM_STATIC]; t_atom *av2=atemp; long ac2=OBEX_UTIL_MAX_ATOM_STATIC;
01640 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_CLEANUP_VAR_STATIC 
01641 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_SETUP_ARRAY_STATIC(ac) t_atom atemp[OBEX_UTIL_MAX_ATOM_STATIC]; t_atom *av2=atemp; long ac2; ac2 = MIN(ac,OBEX_UTIL_MAX_ATOM_STATIC);
01642 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_CLEANUP_ARRAY_STATIC(ac)  
01643 
01644 
01645 //dynamic memory case
01646 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_SETUP_VAR_DYN t_atom *av2=NULL; long ac2=0;
01647 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_CLEANUP_VAR_DYN if (ac2&&av2) mm_freebytes((char *)av2,sizeof(t_atom)*ac2);
01648 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_SETUP_ARRAY_DYN(ac) t_atom *av2=NULL; long ac2=0; av2 = (t_atom *)mm_getbytes(sizeof(t_atom)*ac); ac2 = ac;
01649 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_CLEANUP_ARRAY_DYN(ac) if (ac2&&av2) mm_freebytes(av2,sizeof(t_atom)*ac2);
01650 
01651 
01652 //combo static/dynamic. faster for smaller atom lists on input, but not limited
01653 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_SETUP_VAR_COMBO      OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_SETUP_VAR_DYN    // same for VAR
01654 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_CLEANUP_VAR_COMBO    OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_CLEANUP_VAR_DYN  // same for VAR
01655 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_SETUP_ARRAY_COMBO(ac) \
01656     t_atom atemp[OBEX_UTIL_MAX_ATOM_STATIC]; \
01657     t_atom *av2=atemp; \
01658     long ac2; \
01659     long usestatic=1; \
01660     ac2 = MIN(ac,OBEX_UTIL_MAX_ATOM_STATIC); \
01661     if (ac>OBEX_UTIL_MAX_ATOM_STATIC) { usestatic=0; av2 = (t_atom *)mm_getbytes(sizeof(t_atom)*ac); ac2=ac; }
01662 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_CLEANUP_ARRAY_COMBO(ac) if ((!usestatic)&&ac2&&av2) mm_freebytes((char *)av2,sizeof(t_atom)*ac2);
01663 
01664 
01665 // default to combo
01666 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_SETUP_VAR            OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_SETUP_VAR_COMBO
01667 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_CLEANUP_VAR          OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_CLEANUP_VAR_COMBO
01668 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_SETUP_ARRAY          OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_SETUP_ARRAY_COMBO
01669 #define OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_CLEANUP_ARRAY        OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_CLEANUP_ARRAY_COMBO
01670 
01671 
01672 /**
01673     Flags that determine how functions convert atoms into text (C-strings).
01674     @ingroup atom
01675 */
01676 typedef enum{
01677     OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_GETTEXT_DEFAULT =            0x00000000, ///< default translation rules for getting text from atoms
01678     OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_GETTEXT_TRUNCATE_ZEROS =     0x00000001, ///< eliminate redundant zeros for floating point numbers (default used)
01679     OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_GETTEXT_SYM_NO_QUOTE =       0x00000002, ///< don't introduce quotes around symbols with spaces
01680     OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_GETTEXT_SYM_FORCE_QUOTE =    0x00000004, ///< always introduce quotes around symbols (useful for JSON)
01681     OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_GETTEXT_COMMA_DELIM =        0x00000008, ///< separate atoms with commas (useful for JSON)
01682     OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_GETTEXT_FORCE_ZEROS =        0x00000010, ///< always print the zeros
01683     OBEX_UTIL_ATOM_GETTEXT_NUM_HI_RES =         0x00000020  ///< print more decimal places
01684 } e_max_atom_gettext_flags;

01689 /**
01690     Assign an array of char values to an array of atoms.
01691 
01692     @ingroup    atom
01693     @param      ac              The number of atoms to try to fetch from the array of chars.
01694                                 You should have at least this number of atoms allocated in av.
01695     @param      av              The address to the first of an array of allocated atoms.
01696     @param      count           The number of values in the array specified by vals.
01697     @param      vals            The array from which to copy the values into the array of atoms at av.
01698     @return                     A Max error code.
01699 */
01700 t_max_err atom_setchar_array(long ac, t_atom *av, long count, unsigned char *vals);
01701

01786 
01787 // these variable size calls can alloc mem if desired
01788 
01789 /**
01790     Parse a C-string into an array of atoms.
01791     This function allocates memory for the atoms if the ac and av parameters are NULL.
01792     Otherwise it will attempt to use any memory already allocated to av.
01793     Any allocated memory should be freed with sysmem_freeptr().
01794     
01795     @ingroup    atom
01796     @param      ac          The address of a variable to hold the number of returned atoms.
01797     @param      av          The address of a #t_atom pointer to which memory may be allocated and atoms copied.
01798     @param      parsestr    The C-string to parse.
01799     @return                 A Max error code.
01800     
01801     @remark     The following example will parse the string "foo bar 1 2 3.0" into an array of 5 atoms.
01802                 The atom types will be determined automatically as 2 #A_SYM atoms, 2 #A_LONG atoms, and 1 #A_FLOAT atom.
01803     @code
01804     t_atom *av =  NULL;
01805     long ac = 0;
01806     t_max_err err = MAX_ERR_NONE;
01807     
01808     err = atom_setparse(&ac, &av, "foo bar 1 2 3.0");
01809     @endcode
01810 */
01811 t_max_err atom_setparse(long *ac, t_atom **av, char *parsestr);
01812 
01813 
01814 t_max_err atom_setbinbuf(long *ac, t_atom **av, void *buf);
01815 
01816 
01817 t_max_err atom_setattrval(long *ac, t_atom **av, t_symbol *attrname, t_object *obj);
01818 
01819 
01820 t_max_err atom_setobjval(long *ac, t_atom **av, t_object *obj);
01821 
01822 
01823 
01824 
01825 /**
01826     Create an array of atoms populated with values using sprintf-like syntax.
01827     atom_setformat() supports clfdsoaCLFDSOA tokens 
01828     (primitive type scalars and arrays respectively for the 
01829     char, long, float, double, #t_symbol*, #t_object*, #t_atom*).
01830     It also supports vbp@ tokens (obval, binbuf, parsestr, attribute).
01831 
01832     This function allocates memory for the atoms if the ac and av parameters are NULL.
01833     Otherwise it will attempt to use any memory already allocated to av.
01834     Any allocated memory should be freed with sysmem_freeptr().
01835     
01836     @ingroup    atom
01837 
01838     @param      ac          The address of a variable to hold the number of returned atoms.
01839     @param      av          The address of a #t_atom pointer to which memory may be allocated and atoms copied.
01840     @param      fmt         An sprintf-style format string specifying values for the atoms.
01841     @param      ...         One or more arguments which are to be substituted into the format string. 
01842 
01843     @return     A Max error code.
01844     @see        atom_getformat()
01845     @see        atom_setparse()
01846 */
01847 t_max_err atom_setformat(long *ac, t_atom **av, char *fmt, ...); 
01848 
01849 
01850 /**
01851     Retrieve values from an array of atoms using sscanf-like syntax.
01852     atom_getformat() supports clfdsoaCLFDSOA tokens 
01853     (primitive type scalars and arrays respectively for the 
01854     char, long, float, double, #t_symbol*, #t_object*, #t_atom*).
01855     It does not support vbp@ the tokens found in atom_setformat().
01856     
01857     @ingroup    atom
01858 
01859     @param      ac          The number of atoms to parse in av.
01860     @param      av          The address of the first #t_atom pointer in an array to parse.
01861     @param      fmt         An sscanf-style format string specifying types for the atoms.
01862     @param      ...         One or more arguments which are address of variables to be set according to the fmt string. 
01863 
01864     @return     A Max error code.
01865     @see        atom_setformat()
01866 */
01867 t_max_err atom_getformat(long ac, t_atom *av, char *fmt, ...);
01868 
01869 
01870 /**
01871     Convert an array of atoms into a C-string.
01872     
01873     @ingroup    atom
01874 
01875     @param      ac          The number of atoms to fetch in av.
01876     @param      av          The address of the first #t_atom pointer in an array to retrieve.
01877     @param      textsize    The size of the string to which the atoms will be formatted and copied.
01878     @param      text        The address of the string to which the text will be written.
01879     @param      flags       Determines the rules by which atoms will be translated into text.
01880                             Values are bit mask as defined by #e_max_atom_gettext_flags.
01881 
01882     @return     A Max error code.
01883     @see        atom_setparse()
01884 */
01885 t_max_err atom_gettext(long ac, t_atom *av, long *textsize, char **text, long flags);
01886 
01887 
01888 /**
01889     Fetch an array of char values from an array of atoms.
01890 
01891     @ingroup    atom
01892     @param      ac              The number of atoms allocated in the av parameter.
01893     @param      av              The address to the first of an array of allocated atoms.
01894     @param      count           The number of values to fetch from the array specified by vals.
01895     @param      vals            The address of the array to which is copied the values from av.
01896     @return                     A Max error code.
01897 */
01898 t_max_err atom_getchar_array(long ac, t_atom *av, long count, unsigned char *vals);
01899 
01900 
01901 /**
01902     Fetch an array of long integer values from an array of atoms.
01903 
01904     @ingroup    atom
01905     @param      ac              The number of atoms allocated in the av parameter.
01906     @param      av              The address to the first of an array of allocated atoms.
01907     @param      count           The number of values to fetch from the array specified by vals.
01908     @param      vals            The address of the array to which is copied the values from av.
01909     @return                     A Max error code.
01910 */
01911 t_max_err atom_getlong_array(long ac, t_atom *av, long count, long *vals);
01912 
01913 
01914 /**
01915     Fetch an array of 32bit float values from an array of atoms.
01916 
01917     @ingroup    atom
01918     @param      ac              The number of atoms allocated in the av parameter.
01919     @param      av              The address to the first of an array of allocated atoms.
01920     @param      count           The number of values to fetch from the array specified by vals.
01921     @param      vals            The address of the array to which is copied the values from av.
01922     @return                     A Max error code.
01923 */
01924 t_max_err atom_getfloat_array(long ac, t_atom *av, long count, float *vals);
01925

02017 /**
02018     Convenience wrapper for object_method_typed() that uses atom_setparse() to define the arguments.
02019 
02020     @ingroup    obj
02021     @param      x           The object to which the message will be sent.
02022     @param      s           The name of the method to call on the object.
02023     @param      parsestr    A C-string to parse into an array of atoms to pass to the method.
02024     @param      rv          The address of an atom to hold a return value.
02025     @return     A Max error code.
02026     
02027     @see        object_method_typed()
02028     @see        atom_setparse()
02029 */
02030 t_max_err object_method_parse(t_object *x, t_symbol *s, char *parsestr, t_atom *rv);
02031 t_max_err object_method_binbuf(t_object *x, t_symbol *s, void *buf, t_atom *rv);
02032 t_max_err object_method_attrval(t_object *x, t_symbol *s, t_symbol *attrname, t_object *obj, t_atom *rv);
02033 t_max_err object_method_objval(t_object *x, t_symbol *s, t_object *obj, t_atom *rv);
02034 
02035 /**
02036     Convenience wrapper for object_method_typed() that uses atom_setformat() to define the arguments.
02037 
02038     @ingroup    obj
02039     @param      x           The object to which the message will be sent.
02040     @param      s           The name of the method to call on the object.
02041     @param      rv          The address of an atom to hold a return value.
02042     @param      fmt         An sprintf-style format string specifying values for the atoms.
02043     @param      ...         One or more arguments which are to be substituted into the format string. 
02044     @return     A Max error code.
02045     
02046     @see        object_method_typed()
02047     @see        atom_setformat()
02048 */
02049 t_max_err object_method_format(t_object *x, t_symbol *s, t_atom *rv, char *fmt, ...);

02292 // general object constructors for objects with typed constructors
02293 
02294 /**
02295     Create a new object with one or more atoms parsed from a C-string.
02296     The object's new method must have an #A_GIMME signature.
02297 
02298     @ingroup    attr
02299     @param      name_space  The namespace in which to create the instance. Typically this is either #CLASS_BOX or #CLASS_NOBOX.
02300     @param      classname   The name of the class to instantiate.
02301     @param      parsestr    A C-string to parse into an array of atoms to set the attribute value.
02302 
02303     @return     A pointer to the new instance.
02304     @see        atom_setparse()
02305     @see        object_new_typed()
02306 */
02307 void *object_new_parse(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *classname, char *parsestr);
02308 void *object_new_binbuf(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *classname, void *buf);
02309 void *object_new_attrval(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *classname, t_symbol *objattrname, t_object *obj);
02310 void *object_new_objval(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *classname, t_object *obj);
02311 void *object_new_format(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *classname, char *fmt, ...);
